A multiplicative principal ordinal 'o' is equivalent to 'omega' raised to some power, or is less than or equal to 2.

type: ‚àÄ {o : Ordinal.{u_1}}, Ordinal.Principal (fun x x_1 => x * x_1) o ‚Üî o ‚â§ 2 ‚à® ‚àÉ a, o = Ordinal.omega ^ Ordinal.omega ^ a
name: Ordinal.principal_mul_iff_le_two_or_omega_opow_opow
docString: A multiplicative principal ordinal 'o' is equivalent to 'omega' raised to some power, or is less than or equal to 2.

This theorem states that a natural number is odd if and only if its remainder when divided by 4 is either 1 or 3. In other words, it characterizes odd numbers in terms of their residues modulo 4.

name: Nat.odd_mod_four_iff
docString: This theorem states that a natural number is odd if and only if its remainder when divided by 4 is either 1 or 3. In other words, it characterizes odd numbers in terms of their residues modulo 4.

No zero divisors.

name: CanonicallyOrderedCommSemiring.eq_zero_or_eq_zero_of_mul_eq_zero
docString: No zero divisors.

For any seminormed additive commutative group E, subset s, and real number Œ¥, the set {x : E | ‚à•x‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥ ‚à® x ‚àà s} equals the set {x : E | ‚à•x - o ‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥}, where o is the origin of E.

type: ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : SeminormedAddCommGroup E] (Œ¥ : ‚Ñù) (s : Set E), Metric.ball 0 Œ¥ + s = Metric.thickening Œ¥ s
name: ball_add_zero
docString: For any seminormed additive commutative group E, subset s, and real number Œ¥, the set {x : E | ‚à•x‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥ ‚à® x ‚àà s} equals the set {x : E | ‚à•x - o ‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥}, where o is the origin of E.

The theorem `Odd.ne_two_of_dvd_nat` asserts that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, if `n` is an odd number, and `m` divides `n`, then `m` cannot be `2`. This means that `2` cannot be a factor of an odd number. In more mathematical terms, for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, if there exists a natural number `k` such that `n = 2*k + 1` (implying `n` is odd) and `m` divides `n`, then `m` must not equal `2`.

type: ‚àÄ {m n : ‚Ñï}, Odd n ‚Üí m ‚à£ n ‚Üí m ‚â† 2
name: Odd.ne_two_of_dvd_nat
docString: The theorem `Odd.ne_two_of_dvd_nat` asserts that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, if `n` is an odd number, and `m` divides `n`, then `m` cannot be `2`. This means that `2` cannot be a factor of an odd number. In more mathematical terms, for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, if there exists a natural number `k` such that `n = 2*k + 1` (implying `n` is odd) and `m` divides `n`, then `m` must not equal `2`.

`-2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `3` mod `8`.

type: ‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p ‚â† 2 ‚Üí (IsSquare (-2) ‚Üî p % 8 = 1 ‚à® p % 8 = 3)
name: ZMod.exists_sq_eq_neg_two_iff
docString: `-2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `3` mod `8`.

The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers.

If n is odd, then the Dihedral group of order $2n$ has $n(n+3)$ pairs of commuting elements.

type: ‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï}, Odd n ‚Üí Nat.card { p // Commute p.1 p.2 } = n * (n + 3)

docString: If n is odd, then the Dihedral group of order $2n$ has $n(n+3)$ pairs of commuting elements.
